entry.title: Hulling
entry.summary:
Hulling

For a hundred years I had lain
in the bedrock
heavy, penitent, waiting.
This stone could not be wrought.
Turn it to silt, scattering in water and wind.
Till then, let me be
numb, untouched.

Then, springtime comes, looks on me and there have been a thousand springtimes. Still …
entry.content:
Hulling

For a hundred years I had lain
in the bedrock
heavy, penitent, waiting.
This stone could not be wrought.
Turn it to silt, scattering in water and wind.
Till then, let me be
numb, untouched.

Then, springtime comes, looks on me and there have been a thousand springtimes. Still, a warm ray is flickering on my face and I — Don't dare tend to it. But something is stirring. Betraying change.

entry.title: Stages of Cognitive Development in Children (Piaget)
entry.summary:
Stages of Cognitive Development in Children (Piaget)

Theory

operation
an interiorized action; a logical structure which marks the essence of knowledge according Piaget
mental representation or construction of an object as a thing that can be manipulated
  1. sensorimotor stage (0-18 mos.)
    1. object permanence
    2. practical space
    3. temporal succession
    4. no operations yet …
entry.content:
Stages of Cognitive Development in Children (Piaget)

Theory

operation
an interiorized action; a logical structure which marks the essence of knowledge according Piaget
mental representation or construction of an object as a thing that can be manipulated
  1. sensorimotor stage (0-18 mos.)
    1. object permanence
    2. practical space
    3. temporal succession
    4. no operations yet, only practical knowledge, a substructure
  2. preoperational stage
    1. symbolic function, representational knowledge, a substructure, follows from practical knowledge
    2. no conservation (required for reversible operations)
      1. list the types of conservation-based reversible operations
  3. formal operational stage
    1. classifcation
    2. ordering
    3. number
    4. spatial
    5. temporal
    6. elementary logic of classes and relations
  4. formal operational stage

entry.content:
You Will Never Graduate Lmao

Index

PSY-SPEC Program Requirements

8/25

  • 12.5 CR (25 courses)
    • 3.0 CR (6 courses) C/D-level
    • 1.0 CR (2 courses) D-level

Introduction to Pyschology (1 CR, 2 courses)

  • PSYA01*
  • PSYA02*

Total: 2/25

Laboratory Methods(1.5 CR, 3 courses)

  • PSYB70*
  • PSYC70*
  • PSYC75 → IPR

Total: 4/25

Statistical Methods (1 CR, 2 courses)

  • PSYB07*
  • PSYC08

Total: 8/25

Scientific Communication (0.5 CR, 1 course)

  • PSYC02* → IPR

History of Psychology (0.5 CR, 1 course)

  • PSYC85* → IPR

Social/Developmental B/C-level (2 CR, 4 courses)

Perception/Cognition/Physiology B/C-level (2 CR, 4 courses)

Social/Developmental Seminar D-level (0.5 CR, 1 course)

Perception/Cognition/Physiology D-level (0.5 CR, 1 course)

Additional B/C/D-level (2 CR, 4 courses)

Additional C-level (1 CR, 2 courses)

Thesis Course (½) (0.5 CR, 1 course) - [x] PSYD98

entry.title: Interpersonal Relationships Paper
entry.summary:
Interpersonal Relationships Paper: The Female Dating Strategy

  • Paper should be critiquing pop psych dating advice
  • FDS is an interesting angle because we're inundated with redpill/manosphere content (in psych too, lots of papers about incels) but their distaff counterparts are understudied
  • the official FDS blog uses psych in their articles …
entry.content:
Interpersonal Relationships Paper: The Female Dating Strategy

  • Paper should be critiquing pop psych dating advice
  • FDS is an interesting angle because we're inundated with redpill/manosphere content (in psych too, lots of papers about incels) but their distaff counterparts are understudied
  • the official FDS blog uses psych in their articles
  • vetting strats?
    • probably stereotypes about men to avoid on dating apps & rationale
    • cohabitation
      • on SES
      • FDS is anti-cohabitation because it allows men to defer their proposals ("why buy the cow when you can get the milk for free?")

entry.content:
Middle Childhood Midterm

Fleeting

  • relationship between exercise and brain goes both ways
    • cognitive upgrades
    • embodied cognition
      • selective attention
      • RT
  • childhood obesity
    • 95th percentile
  • childhood overweight
    • 85th percentile
  • social exclusion is an issue
  • what is asthma
  • obesity and asthma lead to social exclusion
  • obesity and parenting
  • obesity rates rise if
    • formula and solid foods before 4 mos .
    • tv in bedroom and drink soda by preschool (early childhood)
    • middle childhood lack sleep, watch screens, don't play outside
  • pester power: the ability to get adults to do what they want
    • fewer kids = |^ pester power
  • boring stats about obesity
    • causes more deaths than malnutrtion
  • hygiene hypothesis: children are overprotected from viruses and bacteria, weakened immune system
    • more common in first-borns, C-section babies less common on the farm
    • link to allergies?
    • words
      • remediate
      • senescence
    • define
      • developmental psychopathology
      • comorbid
      • childhood obesity vs. childhood overweight
      • pester power
      • embodied cognition
      • selective attention
      • reaction time
      • developmental psychopathology
    • which kids will likely develop asthma?
      • which kids will likely develop allergies
        • hygiene hypothesis
    • physical health and social exclusion in middle childhood
      • obesity
      • isolation
      • asthma
  • four principles of developmental psychopathology
    1. abnormal is normal, normal is abnormal
      1. not everyone is neurodivergent. most people are just weird
    2. disabilities change
    3. prognosis is uncertain
    4. diagnosis and treatment of psychopathology are dependent on societal context (macro or micro? look up that guy brofenbrenner baum ferger or wtv)
  • define:
    • aptitude: potential to master a specific skill or learn a certain body of knowledge
    • intelligence the ability to learn and understand various aspects of life; conventionally referring to reading and math, increasingly arts, movement, and social interactions
  • OG IQ formula:
    • mental age/chronological age * 100
      • mental age: mean age associated with a particular test score
  • define:
    • achievement test
      • how is it different from an aptitude test?
  • achievement vs. aptitude
  • define:
    • the flynn effect
    • more apparent for women
    • g: is calculated based on the average mental age of people of a particular chronological age.
  • IQ
    • vocabulary is critical :)
    • for g: speed & memory are crucial
  • intelligence can grow
    • neuroplasticity link
  • theory: multiple intelligences
    • Robert Sternberg and Howard Gardner
    • sternberg:
      • analytic
      • creative
      • practical (didn't aristotle have that with pragmatic intelligence?)
      • may not be academic achievers but fluorish later
      • theory: seven multiple intelligences (Gardner)
        • verbal-linguistic
        • logical-mathematical,
        • musical
        • intrapersonal
        • interpersonal
        • bodily-kinesthetic
        • spatial
        • plus 2
          • naturalistic
          • spiritiual
  • achievement does not reflect aptitude; cultural bieases
  • brain scans
    • do not correlation w/ IQ in childhood (maye we just dont know how to look) ut they do later on
    • can measure RT (link to RT) which → adult IQ
    • less brain activity ≠ less intelligence
      • opposite might be true
      • maybe treatmant resistance
    • sMRI
      • thicker cortex sometimes correlated with high IQ
        • but in 9-11-yr-olds, high vocabulary related to thinner cortex and vocab is part of g and academic achievement

Note Clusters

  • Intelligence
    • Intelligence
      • Flynn Effect
        • Women
    • Aptitude vs. Achievement
    • Measuring Intelligence: Calculating IQ & g
      • Vocabulary
      • Speed & Memory
    • Multiple Intelligences
      • Howard Gardner - 7
      • Robert Sternberg - 3
        • Aristotle
  • Executive Functions
    • Reaction Time
    • Executive Functions
      • Selective Attention
      • Delayed Gratification
      • Emotional Regulation
      • Motivation
  • Parenting
  • Physical Health and Brain Development
    • BMI
    • Obesity
    • Asthma
      • Hygiene Hypothesis
        • Allergies
  • Developmental Psychopathology
    • Four Principles
      • Comorbidity
  • Statistics
  • Remediate
  • Senesence
  • Physical Development Milestones
  • Development of Motor Skills
